intro: Zauschneria tomentella, commonly known as the woolly poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family and is characterized by its soft, hairy foliage and showy, pinkish-white flowers. The plant typically grows in open, sunny habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. It produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, dark seeds. Zauschneria tomentella is often cultivated for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in well-drained soils.
